results.title: Embrace
results.creator_credit: Northern Metropolitan Institute of TAFE, Arts Education, NMIT, Lindy Macauley and Kerreen Ely-Harper
results.brief_description:
Embrace, launched in May 2000 by the Minister for Community Services, is the second dance film produced by NMIT (Northern Melbourne Institute of TAFE) featuring dancers with disabilities. Having experience of Loup - a film commemorating the year of the ocean, the artists (in Embrace) further explored the notion of creative expression and different spaces for dancers with disabilities.
Embrace was filmed in the green surroundings of Merri Creek and in the urban landscape of concrete and graffiti at the St Georges Rd bypass. The movements and actions were a direct result of interactions between the dancers and the landscape. The film, filled with beauty, humour and warmth, explores the themes of Hamlet’s soliloquy to be or not to be, namely the themes of betrayal, alienation, desire to escape and the place of dreams in our waking lives.
Embrace was funded by the Australian Council for the Arts, the City of Boroondara, the Department of Human Services and NMIT. The dancers had the opportunity during the production to work with professional artists from diverse backgrounds and expertise.
Embrace was screened at numerous national and international film festivals including the Dance on Camera festival in New York, January 2001. The principal artist, Randal Aitkin, gave a live performance at the screening of Embrace in New York. The significance of that event lies in the fact that the NMIT dance student qualified to perform among the elite of world dancers while overcoming difficulties arising from intellectual disability. Excerpts from Embrace appeared in the Arte programs on the National French and German Television Networks between December 2001 and February 2002.

results.title: Et cetera. Episode 6 [Joe Felber Multimedia Installation]
results.creator_credit: Northern Access TV, Michael Costello and David McLauchlan
results.brief_description: Presented by David McLauchlan outside the Australian Centre for Contemporary Art, Melbourne. David interviews multimedia artist Joe Felber and dancer/choreographer Lucy Guerin about their collaborative installation with composer Elliott Gyger entitled “25 songs on 25 lines of 25 words on Art Statement for seven voices and dance” based on Ad Reinhardt’s Black Painting and Art Statement. Following the interviews, there is a presentation of Joe Felber’s 7 minute video on the multimedia performance “25 songs on 25 lines…and dance”.

results.title: Et cetera. Episode 3 [1999 Melbourne Fringe Festival]
results.creator_credit: Northern Access TV, Michael Costello and David McLauchlan
results.brief_description:
Documents the 1999 Melbourne Fringe Festival Parade and the Fringe Furniture Exhibition, including interviews with Virginia Hyam, Fringe Director, and Axel, Fringe Furniture Co-ordinator. The Melbourne Fringe Festival has become an institution since its inception in 1982 when a small group of independent artists gathered together to create a platform to present new and independent art to the community. From those early beginnings the Melbourne-based festival now attracts interstate and international guests and covers a wide variety of arts
performances including outdoor events such as the Annual Parade in Brunswick Street, Fitzroy, the Annual Waiter’s Race, street-theatre and live bands and indoor events including comedy and cabaret, music and theatre. The Fringe Furniture Exhibition allows for young students
and designers an opportunity to show-off their creative ability and caters for non-mainstream pieces. Crazy, outrageous, quirky and even occasionally practical, the Exhibition contains an amazing selection of eclectic pieces as witnessed in this documentary program.
Reporters: Melissa Iaria and Phillip Taylor.

results.title: Blow-up
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, black and white and audio
results.brief_description: ‘Blow up’ is a visual pun. Austrian experimental film-maker, Siegfried Fruhauf, uses discovered footage of a man demonstrating mouth to mouth resuscitation on celluloid. The film is displayed in a way that show-cases the celluloid format as an object, rather than viewing the film with the content frame by frame. As the footage rolls the film is objectively abstracted with penetrating sounds of heavy breathing. As the ‘camera’ pans closer, the image takes over and we enter the film. It is our breath that now fills the image.

results.title: Mind's eye
results.brief_description: An experimental animation made with over 1200 photographs. The film revels in situationist surreality and takes the viewer on a roller-coaster journey through a series of locations.

results.title: Technology/transformation: Wonder Woman
results.brief_description: ‘Technology/Transformation: Wonder Woman’ is an incendiary deconstruction of the ideology embedded in television and pop cultural iconography. Through radical manipulation of the female pop icon, Wonder Woman, Birnbaum subverts and reshapes its meaning within the television text.

results.title: Y2K a post mortem
results.brief_description: The global impact of the Millennium Bug runs deep in the commercial and cultural community. Y2K offered consumerist societies not only promise. What were the official responses to the Y2K phenomenon and what was the effect of prophesy on the public imagination and the personal psyche of the electronic age? This post-mortem examined the relationship between millennial tension, popular culture, information technologies, artists and the media, the psychology of mass panic and cultural anxiety, and the Millennium Bug as metaphor for collective apocalyptic fears.

results.title: Lost book found
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, black and white and colour and audio
results.brief_description: The result of over five years of Super 8 and 16mm filming on New York City streets, ‘Lost Book Found’ melds documentary and narrative approaches into a complex meditation on city life. The piece revolves around a mysterious notebook filled with obsessive listings of places, objects, and incidents which serve as the key to a hidden city. It is a city on unconsidered geographies and layered artefacts - the relics of low-level capitalism and the debris of countless forgotten narratives. The project stems from the filmmaker’s first job in New York - working as a pushcart vendor on Canal Street. As usual, Cohen shot in hundreds of locations using unobtrusive equipment and generally without any crew. Influenced by the work of Walter Benjamin, Cohen created ‘an archive of undirected shots and sounds, then set out to explore the boundary’ between genres. During the process Cohen said, ‘I found connections between the street vendor, Benjamin’s ‘flaneur’ and my own work as an observer and collector of ephemeral street life’.

results.title: Liquid Sun (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Apace Research and Sydney University Television Services
results.brief_description: The production of power alcohol from farm crops, and its uses as motor fuel is causing great interest in Australia. It is a major challenge facing primary producers and could be an economic proposition in many areas
results.creator_credit_for_label: Apace Research and Sydney University Television Services
